relation: On Jun 21, 2009, plutodrive from Denver, CO (Zone 5b) wrote: Also known as Agastache 'Pstessene'.

On Apr 13, 2009, DenverJude from Denver, CO (Zone 5b) wrote: I planted this in a raised bed area in full sun last summer. It thrived with very little water, producing beautiful reddish-orange blooms with a purple cast to the sepals. It survived a -20 degree cold snap in December and so far this spring the crown has already tripled in size from last year. It seems to be doing fine with our extreme weather swings so typical of springtime in Denver (80 degrees one day followed by a hard freeze the next and repeated several times Feb - April). This is one tough plant!
On Jan 3, 2009, Lupine12 from Napoleon, OH (Zone 5b) wrote: Very nice plant. 2007 was my first year to grow it. It is a unique shade of yellow and it attracts hummingbirds.
On Nov 20, 2006, Marilynbeth from Hebron, KY wrote: Beautiful shade of Agastache to blend in with other plants and for attracting Hummingbirds. Got it locally at a garden center in 2005.

On Aug 3, 2005, LarryDavid from Salt Lake City, UT (Zone 5b) wrote: Very interesting plant. The foilage smells like root beer and the flowers are very attractive to hummingbirds. One of my favorite xeric plants.
pageTitle: PlantFiles: Detailed information on Orange Hummingbird Mint, Jewel of the Sierra Madre, Hyssop Agastache aurantiaca 'Coronado'
